NPA and City/Town Search Results | accessdate = 2007-01-18}}</ref> |website = [http://www.lakewoodcity.org/ lakewoodcity.org] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 06-39892{{GR|2}} |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 1660883{{GR|3}} |footnotes = }} <!-- Infobox ends -->
'''Lakewood''' is a city in [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]], [[California]], [[United States]]. The population was 80,048 at the 2010 census. It is bordered by [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] on the west and south, [[Bellflower, California|Bellflower]] on the north, [[Cerritos, California|Cerritos]] on the northeast, [[Cypress, California|Cypress]] on the east, and [[Hawaiian Gardens, California|Hawaiian Gardens]] on the southeast. Major thoroughfares include Lakewood ([[California State Route 19|SR 19]]), Bellflower, and Del Amo Boulevards and Carson and South Streets. The [[San Gabriel River Freeway]] ([[Interstate 605 (California)|I-605]]) runs through the city's eastern regions.
Sometimes called "an instant city" because of its originsâgoing from [[lima bean]] fields in 1950 to a well-developed city by 1960âLakewood is, along with [[Levittown, New York]], the archetypal post-[[World War II]] American [[suburb]]. The vast majority of its housing stock is small, mass-produced single-story houses on tree-lined streets, sold initially to World War II and Korean War veterans who worked in the aerospace factories of Long Beach and the [[South Bay, Los Angeles|South Bay]].
==History, notable features== Lakewood is a planned, post-World War II community.<ref name=Rethink>{{cite book|last=Dear|first=Michael J.|coauthors= H. Eric Schockman, Greg Hise|title=Rethinking Los Angeles|publisher=SAGE|year=1996|pages=99|isbn= 9780803972872}}</ref> Developers Louis Boyar, [[Mark Taper]] and Ben Weingart are credited with "altering forever the map of Southern California".<ref name=Rethink/> Begun in late 1949, the completion of the developers' plan in 1953 helped in the transformation of mass-produced working-class housing from its early phases in the 1930s and 1940s to the reality of the 1950s.<ref name=Rethink/> The feel of this transformation from the point of view of a resident growing up in Lakewood was captured by [[D. J. Waldie]] in his award-winning memoir, {{cite book| url=http://books.google.com/books?id=NtgEEDGqn9cC&printsec=frontcover&dq=inauthor:DJ+inauthor:Waldie&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false| title=Holy Land: A Suburban Memoir}}
Lakewood's primary thoroughfares are mostly [[boulevard]]s with landscaped medians, with [[frontage road]]s on either side in residential districts. Unlike in most similar configurations, however, access to the main road from the frontage road is only possible from infrequently spaced collector streets. This arrangement, hailed by [[urban planning|urban planners]] of the day, is a compromise between the traditional urban grid and the arrangement of winding "drives" and [[cul-de-sac|culs-de-sac]] that dominates contemporary suburban and [[Commuter town|exurban]] design.
Lakewood is credited as a pioneer among California cities in services provision. Although it is an incorporated city, Lakewood contracts for most municipal services, with most of these provided by Los Angeles County and, to a lesser extent, by other public agencies and private industry. Lakewood was the first city in the nation to contract for all of its municipal services when it incorporated as a municipality in 1954, making it the nation's first "[[contract city]]." Many other Los Angeles suburbs, such as Cerritos and [[Diamond Bar, California|Diamond Bar]], have adopted the "Lakewood Plan."
Lakewood is the home of the first [[Denny's]] Restaurant. In 1953 Harold Butler founded Dannyâs Donuts, which was renamed Denny's Restaurant in 1959.
Lakewood was named ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'''s "Sportstown USA" in 2005 for the State of California.
==Geography== Lakewood is located at {{Coord|33|50|51|N|118|7|12|W|city}} (33.847365, -118.119889).{{GR|1}}
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|9.5|sqmi|km2}}. {{convert|9.4|sqmi|km2}} of it is land and {{convert|0.1|sqmi|km2}} of it (0.54%) is water.
==Demographics== ===2010=== The [[2010 United States Census]]<ref>{{USCensus-2010CA}}</ref> reported that Lakewood had a population of 80,048. The [[population density]] was 8,456.4 people per square mile (3,265.0/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of Lakewood was 44,820 (56.0%) [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 6,973 (8.7%) [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 564 (0.7%) [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 13,115 (16.4%) [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]] (8.1% Filipino, 1.5% Korean, 1.4% Chinese, 1.4% Cambodian, 1.2% Vietnamese, 0.7% Japanese, 0.6% Indian, 0.4% Thai), 744 (0.9%) [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 9,249 (11.6%) from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 4,583 (5.7%) from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 24,101 persons (30.1%); 24.1% of Lakewood is Mexican, 0.8% Salvadoran, 0.7% Puerto Rican, 0.5% Guatemalan, 0.4% Cuban, 0.3% Peruvian, 0.2% Nicaraguan, 0.2% Honduran, 0.2% Colombian, and 0.2% Ecuadorian.
The Census reported that 79,939 people (99.9% of the population) lived in households, 109 (0.1%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 0 (0%) were institutionalized.
There were 26,543 households, out of which 10,649 (40.1%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 14,711 (55.4%) were [[marriage|opposite-sex married couples]] living together, 3,975 (15.0%) had a female householder with no husband present, 1,696 (6.4%) had a male householder with no wife present. There were 1,262 (4.8%) [[POSSLQ|unmarried opposite-sex partnerships]], and 283 (1.1%) [[same-sex partnerships|same-sex married couples or partnerships]]. 4,719 households (17.8%) were made up of individuals and 1,965 (7.4%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.01. There were 20,382 [[family (U.S. Census)|families]] (76.8% of all households); the average family size was 3.41.
The population was spread out with 19,476 people (24.3%) under the age of 18, 7,593 people (9.5%) aged 18 to 24, 22,117 people (27.6%) aged 25 to 44, 21,776 people (27.2%) aged 45 to 64, and 9,086 people (11.4%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 37.5 years. For every 100 females there were 94.3 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 90.8 males.
There were 27,470 housing units at an average density of 2,902.0 per square mile (1,120.5/kmÂ²), of which 19,131 (72.1%) were owner-occupied, and 7,412 (27.9%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 1.1%; the rental vacancy rate was 5.7%. 57,591 people (71.9% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 22,348 people (27.9%) lived in rental housing units.
===2000=== As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 79,345 people, 26,853 households, and 20,542 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 8,414.8 inhabitants per square mile (3,248.7/kmÂ²). There were 27,310 housing units at an average density of 2,896.3 per square mile (1,118.2/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of the city was 62.67% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 7.34% [[African American (U.S. Census)|Black or African American]], 0.60% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 13.51% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.62% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 10.10% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 5.17% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 22.78% of the population.
There were 26,853 households out of which 38.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.8% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 13.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 23.5% were non-families. 18.4% of all households were made up of individuals and 8.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.95 and the average family size was 3.37.
In the city the population was spread out with 27.5% under the age of 18, 8.1% from 18 to 24, 31.1% from 25 to 44, 21.4% from 45 to 64, and 11.9% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 35 years. For every 100 females there were 93.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 90.1 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $58,214, and the median income for a family was $63,342. Males had a median income of $45,447 versus $35,206 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $22,095. About 5.6% of families and 7.4% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 9.3% of those under age 18 and 7.1% of those age 65 or over.
===Demographic evolution of Lakewood=== {| | valign="top" | {| class="wikitable" ! style="background:#efefef;" | Year ! style="background:#efefef;" | Population |- | 1960 || align="right" | 67,126 |- | 1970 || align="right" | 83,025 |- | 1980 || align="right" | 74,654 |- | 1990 || align="right" | 73,557 |- | 2000 || align="right" | 79,345 |- |} <ref>[http://www.dof.ca.gov/HTML/DEMOGRAP/ReportsPapers/CensusSurveys/Census-Historical/documents/calhist2.xls Demographics] of Lakewood</ref>
==Economy== [[Lakewood Center]] is located in Lakewood.
===Top Employers=== According to the City's 2010 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report,<ref name="cafr">[http://www.lakewoodcity.org/civica/filebank/blobdload.asp?BlobID=5955 City of Lakewood Comprehensive Annual Financial Report]</ref> the top employers in the city are:
{| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! # ! Employer ! # of Employees |- | 1 |[[Long Beach Unified School District]] |901 |- | 2 |City of Lakewood |604 |- | 3 |[[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]] Department of Children and Family Services |550 |- | 4 |[[Albertsons (SuperValu)|Albertsons]] |500 |- | 5 |[[Bellflower Unified School District]] |418 |- | 6 |Long Beach [[Mazda]] |400 |- | 7 |[[ABC Unified School District]] |360 |- | 8 |[[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]] |317 |- | 9 |Piazza [[McDonald's]] |258 |- | 10 |Pacific [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] |311 |- |}
==Politics== In the [[California State Legislature|state legislature]] Lakewood is located in the 27th [[California State Senate|Senate]] District, represented by Democrat [[Alan Lowenthal]], and in the 55th and 56th [[California State Assembly|Assembly]] Districts, represented by Democrats [[Warren Furutani|Warren T. Furutani]] and [[Tony Mendoza]] respectively. Federally, Lakewood is located in [[California's 39th congressional district]], which has a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index|Cook PVI]] of D +13<ref>{{cite web | title = Will Gerrymandered Districts Stem the Wave of Voter Unrest? | publisher = Campaign Legal Center Blog | url=http://www.clcblog.org/blog_item-85.html | accessdate = 2008-02-10}}</ref> and is represented by Democrat [[Linda SÃ¡nchez]].
==Emergency services== {{Ref improve section|date=January 2010}} Fire protection in Lakewood is provided by the [[Los Angeles County Fire Department]] with ambulance transport by [[Care Ambulance Service]].
The [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]] operates the Lakewood Station in Lakewood.<ref>"[http://www.lasd.org/stations/for3/lakewood/index.html Lakewood Station]." [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]]. Retrieved on January 21, 2010.</ref>
The city of Lakewood operates a police helicopter operation independent of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Aero Bureau. The program is called "[[Sky Knight]]". Begun in 1966, it was the first day and night helicopter patrol program in the nation (aerial units had previously been used for search and rescue).
==Education== ===Primary and secondary schools=== ====Public schools==== The city is served by four school districts.
Several citizens created a group called "The Lakewood Unified School District Organizing Committee ," which aims to establish a "Lakewood Unified School District".<ref>{{cite web|title=The Lakewood Unified School District Organizing Committee |url=http://www.pasleyrealty.com/lusd.htm}}</ref>
=====[[Long Beach Unified School District]]===== [[File:LakewoodHSLakewoodCA.jpg|thumb|[[Lakewood High School (California)|Lakewood High School]]]] Elementary schools serving Lakewood: * Cleveland Elementary School (Lakewood) * Oliver Wendell Holmes Elementary School (Lakewood) * MacArthur Elementary School (Lakewood) * Madison Elementary School (Lakewood) * Riley Elementary School (Lakewood) * Mark Twain Elementary School (Long Beach)
Middle schools serving Lakewood: * Bancroft Middle School<ref>{{cite web|title=Bancroft Middle School |url=http://www.lbusd.k12.ca.us/bancroft/index.htm}}</ref> (Long Beach) * DeMille Middle School<ref>{{cite web|title=DeMille Middle School|url=http://www.lbusd.k12.ca.us/demille/index.htm}}</ref> (Long Beach) * Hoover Middle School<ref>{{cite web|title=Hoover Middle School|url=http://www2.lbusd.k12.ca.us/hoover/index.htm}}</ref> (Lakewood)
K-8 schools serving Lakewood: * Gompers Elementary School (Lakewood) * Monroe School (Lakewood) <!-- http://www.lbusd.k12.ca.us/monroe/home.html (dead link)-->
High schools serving Lakewood: * [[Jordan High School (Long Beach, California)|Jordan High School]] (Long Beach) * [[Lakewood High School (California)|Lakewood High School]] (Lakewood)
===== [[Paramount Unified School District]] =====
K-8 schools serving Lakewood: * Collins Elementary School (Long Beach) * Lakewood Elementary School (Lakewood) * Mokler Elementary School (Paramount)
High schools serving Lakewood: * Paramount High School ([[Paramount, California|Paramount]])
=====[[Bellflower Unified School District]]===== Elementary schools serving Lakewood include: * Stephen Foster Elementary School (Lakewood) * Intensive Learning Center (Lakewood) * Jefferson Elementary School (Bellflower) * Esther Lindstrom Elementary School (Lakewood) * Craig Williams Elementary School (Lakewood)
High schools serving Lakewood include: *[[Mayfair High School]] (Lakewood) * Somerset High School (Bellflower) * Bellflower High School (Bellflower)
===== [[ABC Unified School District]]===== Elementary schools serving Lakewood: * [[Aloha Elementary School]] (Lakewood) * [[Melbourne Elementary School]] (Lakewood) * [[Pat Nixon Elementary School]] (Cerritos) * [[Palms Elementary School]] (Lakewood) * Willow Elementary School (Lakewood)
Middle schools serving Lakewood: * Haskell Junior High School (Cerritos) * Tetzlaff Junior High School (Cerritos)
High schools serving Lakewood: * [[Artesia High School (Lakewood, California)|Artesia High School]] (Lakewood) * [[Cerritos High School]] (Cerritos) * [[Richard Gahr High School]] (Cerritos) * [[Whitney High School (Cerritos, California)|Whitney High School]] (Cerritos)
